Accessibility Guide

Digital Accessibility best practices and resources

Understanding ADA Compliance

The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) ensures equal access to digital content. Learn the fundamentals and why it matters for your business.

âš–ï¸

Legal Requirements

ADA Title III requires places of public accommodation to be accessible. This includes websites for businesses serving the public.

  • âœ“Applies to businesses open to the public
  • âœ“Includes digital properties and websites
  • âœ“WCAG 2.1 Level AA is the standard
ğŸ‘¥

Who It Helps

Accessibility benefits everyone, not just people with disabilities. It creates better user experiences across the board.

  • ğŸ‘ï¸Visual impairments (blind, low vision)
  • ğŸ‘‚Hearing impairments
  • ğŸ¤²Motor disabilities
  • ğŸ§ Cognitive disabilities

Business Benefits

Beyond compliance, accessibility improves SEO, user experience, and opens your business to a larger audience.

  • ğŸ“ˆBetter SEO rankings
  • ğŸŒŸImproved user experience
  • ğŸ¯Larger target audience
  • ğŸ›¡ï¸Reduced legal risk

WCAG 2.1 Guidelines

The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines provide the framework for accessible web design. Follow these principles to ensure compliance.

ğŸ‘ï¸

1. Perceivable

Information must be presentable in ways users can perceive, regardless of their abilities.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸Provide alt text for images
  • ğŸ“Use proper heading structure
  • ğŸ¨Ensure sufficient color contrast
  • ğŸ“±Make content adaptable to different presentations
âŒ¨ï¸

2. Operable

User interface components must be operable by everyone, including keyboard-only users.

  • âŒ¨ï¸Keyboard accessible navigation
  • â±ï¸Give users enough time to read content
  • ğŸš«Avoid content that causes seizures
  • ğŸ¯Help users navigate and find content
ğŸ¤”

3. Understandable

Information and operation of the interface must be understandable to all users.

  • ğŸ“–Use clear, simple language
  • ğŸ”„Make content appear and operate predictably
  • â—Provide clear error messages
  • ğŸ·ï¸Label form fields clearly
ğŸ”§

4. Robust

Content must be robust enough to work with various assistive technologies.

  • ğŸ—ï¸Use valid, semantic HTML
  • ğŸ”§Ensure compatibility with assistive technologies
  • ğŸ“±Work across different browsers and devices
  • ğŸ”„Maintain accessibility as technology evolves
